comments.body: Topic clarified/probable typo fixed.
It be nice. You can hang them in a 2x2x1 door frame as curtains where you can walk through them

I agree. At least some of them. The oxeye daisy at least should yield white dye rather than light grey dye. I often label my storage systems with dark oak or spruce signs and the black text is hard to read on them and light grey text just looks weird. However it's really hard to find lilies of the valley unless you get really lucky and spawn near a flower forest.
Currently there are 3 flowers that give light gray dye, oxeye daisy, azure bluet, and white tulips. This would be a great opportunity to have white tulips give white dye.
There should also be a ‚Äútwo tall‚Äù variety for each dye/hue
I completely agree. It just makes sense.

Yes, please! And not only stairs, but slabs, too. I've tried making thatched roofs, and the hay bale block simply doesn't cut it.

I have thought about this many times before and was happy to see that I'm not the only one.

We need more options for roofing and hay stairs + slabs would give a more authentic feel for farm and medieval builds.
Stairs slabs and maybe an option to get rid of the red lines

Agreed, I love making realistic like medieval Norse look roofs and I truly believe hay slab or hay stairs will do just the trick. Also I would like also more agey blocks. Instead of looking brand-new I üí¨ think more warped blocks would do too. Or more cracked blocks.

It ain't happening. Since the bed, trapdoor and wood slab are different types of blocks they cannot ever occupy the same 1x1x1 block. If you place a trapdoor on top of a slab, the trapdoor is on the block above the slab, and the bed must sit another block above that.

If you work with lower half slabs, then either the bed must be dug in or must stand out; no other configurations are possible. You can surround it with trapdoors if you want but the entire thingy will stand out.

The ONLY instance where two different blocks are in the same 1x1x1 block area is waterlogging.

I don‚Äôt agree with you:the longbow will be stronger and its arrow will go faster and further but it takes two seconds to relaod it and the normal 1/2 a second the shortbow takes 1/4 a second to be relaoded but it is the the weakest you can check my post on advanced archery to see more details
A recurve bow would be much more powerfull than a normal bow as well. Also a composite bow made from wood, bones and leather would be the absolutely strongest of them all.

Gluing composite bows, assembling short and long bows - the functionality of the workbench.
And fletching involves specialized interaction with arrows - the assembly of arrows with shear tips, crescent tips, armor-piercing tips, the use of different metals in the tips, and much more.
The long bow is not weaker than the average, but it is difficult to shoot from it while sitting (on a horse, for example).

I think this could be a good idea with a little massaging. It would need to account for tool type (wouldn't want to have someone smelt an iron hoe that cost 2 ingots to make and get 6 back) as well as durability. Perhaps the blast furnace would be the appropriate workstation for this since it's more dedicated to smelting ores. In other words, you would always get a single nugget by smelting in a furnace, but smelting in a blast furnace would give better returns.

I think that you should receive a nugget for every ingot used to craft the item + the durability of the item. For example, full durability chestplate = 16 nuggets (8 for the iron used to craft it + 8 for the current durability of the item rounded down). Example 2: half durability axe = 5 nuggets (3 for the iron used to craft it + 1 for the current durability rounded down)

Smelting an tool in a furnace should give you back the ingots used to craft it multiplied by durability % remaining.

For example: half durability iron boots (4 ingots to craft it * .5 durability = 2)

The formula I would suggest is:
ceiling(8*durability_percentage*ingots_to_craft)
In other words, you get back 8/9 of the material in proportion to the durability. This way every item will always give one nugget and will give up to 64 nuggets for a full durability chest plate. This is totally linear and pretty balanced, so if the yield feels too high you could reduce that factor from 8 to, say, 5.

EDIT:
I would also add that I think increasing the yield on this is game-balancing. As it is, I would rather throw away extra gear than spend the time, inventory space, and smelting materials to convert it into nuggets. I don't think it is actually worth doing. An entire shulker box of gear yields 3 ingots.

This is good simply because there's no easy way to stop or slow down griefers besides obsidian spam or hard to mine blocks. Having good looking cosmetic obsidian variants would at least stop the power creep advantage griefers have of taking seconds to destroy hours of hard work. Unless we get reinforced normal building blocks to go along with reinforced deepslate, this is the next best thing.

They are like that because they are actually .5 damage points lower in the experimental combat snapshots. Tried to plan ahead :).

As a Japanese, I don't think a normal sword is less damaging than a Japanese sword, but the more you use an actual Japanese sword, the harder it is to cut. How about a specification that maximizes power by adding a system called sharpness and performing sharpness and recovery with a Grindstone or Anvil? As a differentiator, ordinary swords do not need to be sharpened.

This would be perfect for people who create different stories so they can identify them more easily.
Mojang, written and enchanted books cannot stack anyways, why not have them dyable?

With the new library block the ability to dye written and enchanted books would allow the player the ability to create color coded storage for their books. Similar to how we can dye leather armor and horse armor, players could create color coordinated library decor to fit any palette.

Even the possibility to upgrade the spell book by using a smithing table, armor enchantments that reduce cost or cooldown, and more utility spells such as a temporary buffs commonly found in beacons and conduits.

The images could be fixed like the image of the sun and moon in the Overworld, or the End Flash symbol could only appear when there is an End Flash.
How in the world could any of this be a good idea?

This is a cool idea, but I think the Warden should drop something which can be brewed into this potion.
We have striders + that woud just sink cuz of how heavy it would be. This is just bad feedback that doesn't make sense and makes a feature we already have be useless.

Kind of like wireless pistons. I won't lie, that would probably be too much for minecraft to handle, because unlike pistons that move blocks in one direction, magnets would affect multiple directions and cause a mess in game unless you have a good pc. 

However, they could instead be added to affect entities and items. Iron golems, or entities wearing iron armor would be pulled towards it.

I would like if any tool from copper to netherite instead of breaking and disappearing just stays in a broken state where it can't be used anymore (works like if you just used the hand) but keeps the enchantments and can still be repaired and enchanted.

Also the archeology broken tools could have ancient enchantments that are not possible to obtain in any other way. Maybe also enchantments above the max lvl or incompatible enchantments but that's probably too much. Also enchantments have a white name and curses have a red one, would be cool if these had a different color like blue, magenta, yellow or green.

Also a small chance to get an enchanted book with any not exclusive enchantment including these unique ones could be cool to have a small chance to apply these to any tool you want.
